thread.title: NBN boss "not aware" of hacking
thread.title_full: NBN boss "not aware" of hacking | Business Spectator

author: Mitchell Bingeman
title: NBN boss "not aware" of hacking
text:
NBN boss Bill Morrow has denied any wrongdoing or involvement in the hacking of a journalist’s phone that was covered up when he was at the helm of Vodafone Australia.
Fronting a Senate Committee in Canberra today, Mr Morrow said he couldn’t recall the exact details of the hacking incident, which occurred prior to his appointment at Vodafone Australia in 2011 but was uncovered during his watch at the mobile provider in 2012.
Asked repeatedly by Labor senator Stephen Conroy if he had reported the incident to police or other law enforcement agencies, Mr Morrow said the company had taken the proper steps to deal with the issue, including the termination of the employees who committed the crime. He also repeatedly said he could not “recall any of the specific details” about the case.
“If there was any criminal activity that I was aware of I would have made sure it was appropriately dealt with. I feel confident this was the case,” he said.
Mr Morrow was Vodafone Australia chief executive when its Australian fraud investigator, Colin Yates, employed by Vodafone Group in June 2012, raised the hacking concerns — and other serious alleged legal breaches — with the telco giant’s global head of security in London.
Despite those “very serious” ­allegations, Vodafone covered up the hacking of the phone, failing to report it to authorities or notify the journalist, Fairfax investigative ­reporter Natalie O’Brien.
“Any details behind this really need to be referred to Vodafone, it’s not a matter for NBN nor is it a matter for me, Bill Morrow,” Mr Morrow said.
“I reported nothing to the police, Senator, because I was not aware of any of the details that are being currently reported in the news. I had no specific discussions with anybody about any criminal activity outside of Vodafone.”
The January 2011 hacking of O’Brien’s phone by Vodafone — to discover her sources after a story she broke exposing major ­security and privacy concerns at the telco — was revealed by The Weekend Australian on Saturday .
Mr Morrow said Communications Minister Malcolm Turnbull was not told about the incident prior to his appointment as NBN boss.
This story was first published in The Australian Business Review.
